journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Impact patterns and temporal evolutions of water drops impinging on a rotating disc

article-meta.aff: School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, People’s Republic of China.email: jyli@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: The impact process of a water drop colliding with a rotating disc was recorded and analysed using a high-speed video camera. Four falling velocities of the drop, eight rotational speeds, and four impacting radii of the disc were chosen to study their influences on the outcomes of drop impact. The correlation of the deposition–splash boundary was found to be the function of Reynolds number, Weber number, and Rossby number. Four kinds of impact processes were classified in terms of Rossby number and several new stages of the impact outcomes not present in drop impact on a stationary plate were recognized. For deposition processes, the temporal evolutions of two spread factors, the tangential and radial spread factors, were analysed in detail. It was found that the Rossby number and the falling velocity of the drop are the major factors affecting the tangential spread factor. In contrast, the Rossby number has little effect on the radial spread factor while the falling velocity of the drop still exerts a considerable influence on it.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The impact of water drops on rotor blades or impellers can be observed in almost all types of turbomachines. A well-known example is the collision of high-speed coarse water drops with rotor blades in wet stages of steam turbines, which would cause erosion or mechanical failure of blades [1–3]. Others include water atomization by rotor blades in an axial-flow spay fan (a key element in the new washer air conditioning in textile factories), wet compression in axial compressors [4], and water spray in centrifugal compressors and fans to prevent ash or tar from accumulating in flow passages. Besides, rain ingestion in axial-flow compressors [5] of aircraft engines operating at idle power and icing ofwater droplets on windturbine blades pose a threat to stable operations of turbomachines.

Although knowledge of the impact process and theunderlying mechanism of drop impact on rotors is important to prevent its accompanying damages and to achieve full potential of its benefits, little information is available. As a result, Williams and Young [6] had to assume the water friction factor instead of calculating it via numerical methods in simulating the movement of deposited water on rotor blade surfaces. The friction factor is an important parameter in above simulations, but only whenthe profile of water film on rotor surfaces has been known, can it be computed directly. In addition, empirical droplet-splashing models based on the data of drops impacting on stationary surfaces have to be adopted in simulating drop collision with rotorsurfaces, for no models taking account of the rotational effect of the rotor on drop impact processes have been presented. An example is the investigation of drop collision with rotor surfaces in a transonic compressor rotor by Sun et al. [4]. However, only two extreme cases, the one that all drops deposit on blade surfaces and the other that all drops break up into smaller droplets, were computed in their study, due to the lack of the knowledge of how and when theimpact drops break up or deposit on rotor bladesurfaces.

The experiment on drops impacting on a rotating disc can provide answers to the above questions to a certain extent, such as under what conditions the drop would splash, how the deposited drop evolves in the impact process, and how the inertial centrifugal and Coriolis forces influence the impact process of a drop on rotor surfaces.

Despite vast investigations on drop impact on stationary surfaces ranging from different review papers [7–10] and experimental and numerical papers on the deposition process and spread factor [11–17] to papers on the splash process and the deposition–splash limit (boundary) [18, 19], few papers have been devoted to drop impact on a rotating disctill now, to the best of the authors’ knowledge. As an early attempt, Shalnev et al. [20] conducted an experiment on impact dynamics of a water drop colliding with a rotating disc to simulate the erosion of drops on turbine blades. They reported that in the case of the dry disc, the drop was either partly carried off or was sharply deformed and blown off by theboundary layer before it contacted the disc. Bycontrast, Povarov et al. [21] found that with the increase in the rotational speed of the disc, there existed three types of interactions of the drop with the disc, i.e. the complete adherence to the disc, the partial reflection, and the total reflection of the drop from the disc. However, only a brief description of the partial and total reflection processes was presented intheir paper with a few collision photos. On the other hand, Yao and Cai [22] focused their research on thedynamics of water drops impacting at small angles onthe surface of a heated rotating disc to study the effect of impact angle on heat transfer.

From above discussion, it is clear that little information is available in the literature about impact processes and patterns and the temporal evolution of deposited water drops impacting on a rotating disc. No research has been reported on the deposition–splash boundary. However, these information and data are closely related to the input power and performance of, for example, the spray axial-flow fan, from the authors’ tests and improvement of such fans. The impact patterns and data arealso of fundamental interest to other applications.

In this experimental study, the authors aim at thedeposition–splash boundary and the deposition process of a drop impacting on a rotating disc. The details of the experimental set-up are introduced in Section 2. Section 3 deals with the impact patterns and relevant new stages. The discussion and analysis of experimental results are provided in Section 4, while conclusions are presented in Section 5.

sec.title: 2 EXPERIMENTAL SET-UP
sec.p:
The schematic diagram of the experimental set-up is shown in Fig. 1. The drop was generated by a syringe pump with a flat-tipped needle. An aluminium disc was employed as the rotating disc. Its rotational speed varied using a direct current motor controlled by a DC timing. Fig. 1
Schematic diagram of the experimental set-up

A high-speed video camera (Phantom V7, USA), together with image analysis software (Phantom camera control software), was used to acquire the images of drop impact and to analyse the splash and deposition processes. The image resolution wasset to 800 × 600 pixels, with a frame rate of 2000 frame/s. The camera was placed either almost normal to or nearly parallel with the disc surface for the observation of drop impact.

The drop diameter could be measured from a series of images taken before impact using image analysis software. The mean drop diameter was determined according to formula (1) where Dx is the measured horizontal drop diameter and Dy the vertical one.

The diameter of the drop could also be calculated according to mass conversation law, that is D=6Qvt/(nπ)3. Here, Qv is the volume flow rate of the syringe pump and t the time for generating n drops. The results obtained by the two methods were in good agreement with errors less than 3 per cent. The test conditions of the drops and disc are summarized in Table 1 and the properties of water are determined by referring to handbooks of matter properties. Table 1
Test conditions
Water property and disc length scale Unit Datum
Viscosity mPa·s 1.002
Surface tension mN/m 72.8
Density kg/m3 998.2
Diameter mm 4.425
Radius of disc, R mm 150
Thickness of disc mm 12.5
Surface roughness of disc µm 1.2

The falling velocity of the drop before impact could be calculated according to free-fall law (2) where H is the displacement from the tip of the needle to the disc surface and g the acceleration of gravity.

Figure 2 shows the relative coordinate system bounded to the axis of the rotating disc and the velocity triangle of the drop impacting on the disc. The angle of impact, α, made by the relative velocity with the disc surface is also demonstrated. Fig. 2
Coordinate system and velocity triangle

In the relative or rotating coordinate system, thedimensionless governing equations for incompressible flow contain three dimensionless numbers related to the impact process. They are the Reynoldsnumber, Re = ρVD/μ; the Weber number, We = ρV2D/σ; and the Rossby number, Ro = V/ωRs. The variables in the numbers are the density ρ, falling velocity V, diameter D, viscosity μ, and surface tension σ of the water drop, respectively. Since Rs is the radius at the disc where the drop impact occursand ω the disc angular velocity, Ro number in this article actually represents the tangent of the impact angle, tgα.

The test matrix involved four falling velocities, eightrotational speeds, and four impact radii on the disc, respectively. Unlike the experiments in Shalnev et al. [20] and Povarov et al. [21], the present experiments were conducted at low rotational speeds. The drop kept almost a perfect sphere before contacting the disc and was not blown off but deposited on the disc or splashed after impact; therefore, the effect of the rotating disc induced air boundary layer on thefalling drop was ignored in this study. Table 2 presents the variation range of the test matrix anddimensionless numbers. The experiment was conducted at room temperature of 20°C. Table 2
Variation ranges of the test matrix and dimensionless numbers
Variables Unit Values or range
Falling velocity of drop, V m/s 1.40, 1.98, 3.13, and 4.43
Radius of impact position, Rs mm 45, 75, 100.5, and 130.5
Rotational speed of disc, n r/min 120, 192.7, 276.4, 374.3, 565.5, 817.5, 1144.5, and 1389.8
Impact angle, α Degrees 4.2–82.7
Ro number based on V — 0.074–7.832
Re number based on V — 6172–19 530
We number based on V — 119, 238, 594, and 1191

sec.title: 3 CLASSIFICATION OF IMPACT PATTERNS AND THE RELEVANT NEW STAGES
sec.p: Impact patterns of drops colliding with stationary surfaces, which include the kinematic, spreading, relaxation (receding), and wetting/equilibrium stages, have been a key topic [11–19] for over one hundred years, due to the fundamental interests inmany applications. For the similar reasons, various impact patterns different from those on stationary surfaces will be presented in this article. The impact patterns different from those on stationary surfaces have been classified into four kinds of typical patterns via closely watching and quantitatively analysing thevideos of the impact processes. Their quantitative results will be introduced in Section 4.

sec.title: 3.1 Impact patterns with a high value of Ro number
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the typical impact process consisting of four impact patterns at a high Ro Number. Itoccurred under conditions of n = 120 r/min, V = 1.98 m/s, and α = 74.1°. The impact radius is 45 mm. This leads to Re = 8728, We = 238, and Ro = 3.5, respectively. The camera was positioned over 80° above the disc surface. The tilt of the camera would lead to a relative shortening in the length of less than 8 per cent. Fig. 3
Impact patterns at the conditions of Rs = 45 mm, n = 120 r/min, V = 1.98 m/s, and α = 74.1°: (a) t = 9.5 ms, t* = 4.3; (b) t = 124.0 ms, t* = 55.5; (c) t = 244.0 ms, t* = 109.2; and (d)t = 302.0 ms, t* = 135.1
The impact process on this condition can be classified into four stages: the spreading, receding, transition, and centrifugal movement stages.

In the spreading stage, the drop spreads rapidly upon impact. First, it deforms like a truncated sphere and a lamella with a circular rim appears. Then, the initial kinetic energy of the drop is quickly converted to surface and dissipation energies until the drop approaches its maximum spread diameter, with the kinetic energy decreasing to zero and the surface energy reaching its maximum value. The dimensionless time when the drop reaches its maximum spread diameter is close to that on stationary surfaces [16]. In this period, the perturbation ofthe rim can be observed gradually, as shown in Fig. 3(a). Because the mass-averaged outward displacement in this period is small, the drop obtains little work done by inertial centrifugal force. The less important role of inertial Coriolis force can be verified by the large value of Ro number (Ro = 3.5), which is the ratio of inertial to Coriolis force by definition. Therefore, it can be said that the vertical velocity, viscous force, and surface tension are the main parameters affecting the spreading stage.

In the receding stage, the rim moves inward in a similar way to that on a stationary surface, until it reaches the drop centre (Fig. 3(b)) at t* = 55.5, which is a little later than that on stationary surfaces [16]. The receding movement of the rim occurs under the combined action of surface tension, viscous force, inertial centrifugal, and Coriolis forces. The liquid–solid contact area shrinks rapidly with the lobes on the rim fusing and the lamella thickening, causing a reduction of surface energy and a further increase in dissipation energy. However, the effect of centrifugal and Coriolis forces on drop receding can still be ignored, because the mass-averaged radial movement of the drop is small and the rotational speed of the disc is also low.

Figure 3(c) presents the pattern of the transition stage that cannot be observed for drops on stationary surfaces. In this stage, the quick decrease in the perimeter of the rim and rapid increase in the thickness of the lamella make surface tension and viscous friction forces reduce sharply; thus, the inertial centrifugal force begins to dominate the evolution of the drop. As a result, the receded drop deforms under the action of centrifugal force, deviates from its centre, and tends to move towards the edge of the disc.

After that, the centrifugal movement stage of the drop starts on the rotating disc. The centrifugal force causes the drop to flow in the radial direction, but the inertial Coriolis force pulls the drop to flow away from the radial direction. The overall action of surface tension, viscous, inertial centrifugal, and Coriolis forces makes the drop flow along a spiral curve towards the edge of the disc. As shown in Fig.3(d), the deformed drop in this stage moves like a meteor with a longer and longer tail behind. Such a case was also simulated by Williams and Young [6] (Fig. 8 in their study), but they predicted the trajectory of the drop on a rotating disc by assuming the friction factor K instead of using the shape of the drop to compute the value of K.

sec.title: 3.2 Impact patterns with an intermediate value of Ro number
sec.p:
The typical impact process at an intermediate value of Ro number is presented in Fig. 4. The impact radius is 45 mm. Other experimental parameters are n = 276.4 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s, and α = 67.4°. This corresponds to Re = 13 800, We = 594, and Ro = 2.4, respectively. The camera was still placed around 80° above the disc surface. Fig. 4
Impact patterns at radius of 45 mm with parameters n = 276.4 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s, and α = 67.4°: (a) t = 9.0 ms, t* = 6.4; (b) t = 27.0 ms, t* = 19.1; and (c) t = 55.5 ms, t* = 39.3

Compared with those of Fig. 3, the vertical and tangential velocity components of the drop in the relative system in Fig. 4 are both significantly increased. This leads to rather different impact patterns involving only three stages, i.e. the spreading and receding stages and the stage of development of the ligaments.

The spreading stage is still the first one; however, itsfinal spreading shape (Fig. 4(a)) is a nearly elliptical pattern other than a circle-like one observed inFig. 3(a). This is due to the evident increase in tangential velocity of the drop in the relative system. Accordingly, the spread of the drop in the circumferential direction obviously overweighs its radial spread, with some lobes on the fore side of the rim. In addition, the spreading dimensionless time, t*, also increases.

Then, a vague shrinking of the rim with the development of some lobes into ligaments begins. Some lobes develop into ligaments with sub-drops (the ligament heads) flowing in the reverse direction of the rotation on the disc, as shown in Fig. 4(b), which is quite different from the phenomena in the receding stage in Fig. 3. In the meantime, some liquid at the inner side of the rim (the side near the rotating axis) begins to flow towards the outer side of the rim due to the action of inertial centrifugal force and feeds the outer side. In addition, the lobes are pushed further in the reverse rotation direction under the action of the tangential inertial force, rather than being pulled back by the surface tension. This leads to the ligament formation.

Figure 4(c) shows the final stage, the development of the ligaments. In this stage, the sub-drops in the heads of the ligaments turn their directions towardsthe edge of the disc due to the action of centrifugal force. They flow along a spiral curve under the combined action of the viscous, surface tension, centrifugal, and Coriolis forces, and fly offthe disc at high speeds. The final kinetic energy of the sub-drops in the heads of the ligaments is raised to a high value due to the centrifugal work done by the rotating disc. For this case, the impact patterns are totally different from those of the drops on stationary surfaces and have not been reported in previous papers.

sec.title: 3.3 Impact patterns with a low value of Ro number
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the third typical impact process. The associated parameters are listed as follows: n = 565.5 r/min, V = 1.98 m/s, and α = 18.5° at Rs = 100.5 mm, corresponding to Re = 8728, We = 238, and Ro = 0.33. The camera was positioned 80° above the surface of the rotating disc. Fig. 5
Impact pattern at radius of 100.5 mm with parameters n = 565.5 r/min, V = 1.98 m/s, and α = 18.49°: (a) t = 19.0 ms, t* = 8.5; (b) t = 44.0 ms, t* = 19.7

There are only two typical stages (impact patterns) in this process, the spreading and radial ligament stages, as shown in Fig. 5. In the spreading stage, the tangential velocity (5.92 m/s) of the drop in the relative system is evidently higher than its vertical falling velocity (1.98 m/s), thus the spreading process is mainly determined by its tangential velocity. Inaddition, the perturbation on the fore side of therim is so strong that the lobes directly develop into ligaments, which look like the arms of an octopus, as shown in Fig. 5(a). Unlike the outward flow in Fig. 4 which starts in the receding stage, the flow from the inner side of the rim to the outer side occurs even when the drop still keeps on spreading in the circumferential direction, but it is not as clear as that in Fig. 4. When the flow reaches the outer side ofthe rim, some ligaments, stemming from the outer side of the rim, develop and move along spiral curveson the disc, disintegrate into small droplets at theedge of the disc, and fly off. Figure 5(b) displays the impact pattern of the radial ligament stage.

In this impact process, first the kinetic energy of thedrop is rapidly transferred to its surface energy at the expense of dissipation energy upon impact. The height of the rim is reduced obviously compared with those in Figs 3 and 4. Due to the action of centrifugal force, the liquid on the inner side of the rim quickly reaches the outer side. Then, ligaments from the locations of the lobes on the outer side of therim develop into droplets and flow outward without any receding motion. Finally, the ligament droplets fly off the disc at high speeds with the work done by the centrifugal force. It is obvious that the centrifugal and Coriolis forces dominate such impact process. Such droplet-flying phenomena can also be observed in the centrifugal atomization process [23].

sec.title: 3.4 Splash patterns upon impact
sec.p:
The typical splash patterns are shown in Fig. 6. The associated parameters are summarized as follows: n = 817.5 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s, and α = 15.7° at impact radius of 130.5 mm, corresponding to Re = 13 800, We = 594, and Ro = 0.28. The camera was placed almost horizontally to the disc surface to obtain clear images of the splash process. Fig. 6
Impact pattern at radius of 130.5 mm with parameters n = 817.5 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s, and α = 15.66°: (a) t = 2.0 ms, t* = 1.4; (b) t = 6.5 ms, t* = 4.6

The present investigations reveal a different splash process from those in Povarov et al. [21] and Yao andCai [22]. In Povarov et al. [21], the drop was partly blown off after it contacted the rotating disc and no splash droplets were observed. The diameter of the drop and the tangential velocity in Fig. 2 of Povarov et al. [21] were 2.0 mm and 30 m/s, respectively. In contrast, the tangential velocity of this case is 11.17 m/s and clear pictures of splash corona formation were recorded. On the other hand, Yao and Cai [22] paid attention to the effect of the Leidenfrost temperature on the break-up of waterdrops impacting on a heated rotating disc. The experimental conditions of Yao and Cai [22] were different from the present ones, with no photos being reported.

In this case, the drop splashes after a short period of spreading on the disc and then, a partial or tilting corona appears, as shown in Fig. 6(a). This is the splash stage. After that, the tilting corona breaks up into many smaller droplets, due to the inherent instability of the drop and air resistance. This is classified as the break-up stage (Fig. 6(b)).

The high tangential velocity of the drop was regarded the major contributor to the formation of the tilting corona. When the drop collides with the disc, the fluid near the disc rapidly slows down due to fluid viscosity. Since the fluid above the disc still has a high tangential velocity, it will overtake that fluid in the vicinity of the wall soon. This gives rise to the formation of the tilting corona.

The major mechanism for water spray in the spray axial-flow fan may be found from the above impact patterns, in which some of the water drops remain on the disc while part of the water splashes. This might also be the actual condition that happens in wet compression in an axial compressor, rather than the complete either deposition or splash phenomena assumed in Sun et al. [4].

sec.title: 4 ANALYSES OF EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: Whether a drop will splash or deposit when impacting on rotor blade surfaces is the key issue for many kinds of turbomachines, such as the water spray axial-flow fan and the compressors with wet compression [4]. On the other hand, the spread area and its evolution are essential parameters in the erosion and dust-washing processes of the steam turbine, centrifugal compressor, and fan. Therefore, the quantitative results of the deposition–splash boundary and the temporal evolution of the impact process, such as the spread factor, are very important to obtain predictive capabilities of the impact process.

sec.title: 4.1 Correlation of the deposition–splash boundary in terms of dimensionless numbers
sec.p:
Since Re and We numbers are the major parameters in the dimensionless governing equations for incompressible flow of a drop impacting on stationary drysurfaces, the past correlations of the deposition–splash boundaries based on experimental data areoften expressed as the functions of Re and We numbers [9]. In the relative system of the rotating disc, however, three dimensionless numbers are involved in the dimensionless governing equations for incompressible flow of drop impact. They are Re, We, and Ro numbers. The experimental data of thisstudy are plotted in a diagram with log (We) as the y-coordinate and log (Re×Ro) as the x-coordinate, as shown in Fig. 7. It is interesting to note that the boundary is a linear line, which can be expressed as (3) Fig. 7
Deposition–splash boundary for drops impacting on a rotating disc
This correlation is applicable to the prediction of the occurrence of splash. Further reducing equation (4) gives (4)

Since equations (3) and (4) are deduced on the basis of this study, their applicable scope may need further verification and the power exponents of Re, We, and Ro numbers may not be an exact unit. Equation (4) does indicate, however, the major influence parameters in drop splash on a rotating disc. The splash tendency due to the increase in tangential velocity conforms to the findings in Povarov et al. [21] and Yao and Cai [22]. In Povarov et al. [21], the deposition–splash boundary line was a linear line with V/ωRs equal to a constant, while the correlation of the boundary line in Yao and Cai [22] was expressed as a quadratic polynomial expression in terms of theimpact angle, α. The differences in the experimental conditions may be the major factors for such discrepancies. In addition, the ranges of the experimental variables are also quite different.

Compared with the influences of surface tension and fluid viscosity presented in Table 3 of Rioboo et al. [11], the function of surface tension in of equation (4) on splash acts in the same trend, but that of viscosity does the opposite. The mechanism for the converse influence of viscosity revealed by equation (4) may be due to the high tangential velocity at impact point. A high viscosity of the fluid means a high shear force that the disc imposes on the drop. As pointed out in Yao and Cai [22], this shear force causes distortion and stretching of the drop and makes the drop destabilize significantly.

sec.title: 4.2 Effect of Ro number on the temporal evolution of tangential spread factor at given falling velocities
sec.p: Drop spread is a key parameter in the study of drop collision. Drop spread factor, d/D, is defined as theratio of the length scale of the spreading drop to its original diameter. Since the rim of the drop impacting on a rotating disc displays an elongated shape, there exist two spread factors, the tangential spread factor, dc/D, and the radial spread factor, dr/D, for drop impact on a rotating disc; D is the diameter of the drop before impact, dc the straight-line distance from the fore edge of the rim to its rear edge in the circumferential direction, and dr the maximum width of the rim. The use of a linear line instead of a circular arc as the tangential spread only brings about a less than 0.5 per cent relative error.

In the test matrix, there are three variables, i.e. the impact radius Rs, the rotational speed n of the disc, and the falling velocity V of the drop. In this section, the drop falling velocity V is kept constant to see theinfluence of Rs and n on the temporal evolution of dc/D.

In every diagram of Figs 8 and 9, the rotational speed is kept constant to see the effect of the impact radius (or tangential velocity) on the tangential spread factor. Four impact radii, 45, 75, 100.5, and 130.5 mm, which correspond to the positions of 0.3, 0.5, 0.67, and 0.87 of the disc radius, are chosen. Variation in impact radius also leads to the variation in Ro number. Fig. 8
Influence of impact radius (45, 75, 100.5, and 130.5 mm) on the temporal evolution of the tangential spread factor: (a) n = 120 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s (b) n = 192.7 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s Fig. 9
Influence of impact radius (45, 75, 100.5, and 130.5 mm) on the temporal evolution of the tangential spread factor: (a) n = 276.4 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s; (b) n = 565.5 r/min, V = 3.13 m/s

In Fig. 8(a), all the values of Ro number are large, ranging from 1.92 to 5.53. It is notable that at the very beginning of drop impact, for example, at about t < 2 ms, all the experimental data fall on the same curve. This means that all the spread processes behave in almost the same manner. During this period, the centrifugal and Coriolis forces play a lessimportant role in the evolution of such an impact. The maximum value of tangential spread factor dc/D rises with the decrease in Ro number, so does the time for the drop to reach its maximum spread. All the drops experience a receding movement and the drops with relatively low Ro values take a longer time to finish the receding motion. The impact processes in Fig. 8(b) show similar variation tendencies as those observed in Fig. 8(a). These cases correspond to the impact patterns with a high value of Ro number, as shown in Fig. 3.

The cases in Fig. 9 show different spread patterns due to the increased rotational speed of the disc. As revealed in Fig. 4, the impact processes in Fig. 9(a) only experience a rapid spreading stage and an indistinct receding stage (the ligament length will not be considered here). It can also be observed that the temporal evolution lines in Fig. 9 do not fall on thesame curve from the beginning of the spread stage, which is a major feature in Fig. 8. In addition, the receding motion weakens with the decrease in Ro. The spread patterns in Fig. 5 correspond to the cases in Fig. 9(b), in which the receding motion does not exist at all. Due to the low values of Ro, only the spreading stage is available for such drop impact. Itshould be noted that the time scale in Fig. 9(b) ismuch shorter than those in other subfigures in Figs 8 and 9.

From the temporal evolutions shown in Figs 8 and 9, it is evident that the Ro number plays a more important role in the impact patterns and temporal evolution of dc/D than the impact radius. The lower the value of Ro number is, the more rapid the spread process becomes. Since a rapid and large spread means a severe wash of the drop on the disc surface, an impact at low Ro number may be harmful for wetturbine blades on the one hand and it may be beneficial to wash tar or ash in the flow passages of centrifugal compressors and fans on the other hand.

Another way to change Ro number is to change therotational speed of the disc while keeping the impact radius at disc constant. Such comparison is made in Fig. 10, in which the value of Ro ranges from 0.13 to infinity (corresponding to drop impact on a stationary plate). It is evident that the variation in therotational speed has a noticeable effect on the temporal evolution (the impact pattern) of the drop on a rotating disc. Furthermore, it is noted that although the impact processes are studied from another point of view, the same variation tendency can also be observed, i.e. variation of Ro number exerts considerable influence on impact processes. Fig. 10
Influence of the rotational speed on the temporal evolution of the tangential spread factor Notes: Related parameters are V = 1.98 m/s, Rs = 130.5 mm, n = 0, 192.7, 276.4, 374.3, and 565.5 r/min

sec.title: 4.3 Effects of velocity V and Ro number on the tangential spread factor
sec.p:
Three falling velocities were chosen to study the effectof falling velocity on the tangential spread factor, withthe rotational speed and impact radius kept constant. The results are presented in Fig. 11. Since We and Re numbers will both rise with the falling velocity, only the We number is chosen as the representative of the falling velocity. It is obvious that themaximum tangential spread factor, dc,max/D, increases with We number and so does the spreadingrate. Fig. 11
Effect of drop vertical velocity on tangential spread factor, V = 1.98 m/s, 3.13 m/s, and 4.43 m/s: (a) n = 120 r/min, Rs = 75 mm; (b) n = 276.4 r/min, Rs = 45 mm

Figure 12 presents the experimental results of dc,max/D versus ctgα(the reciprocal of Ro number). The cases at two falling velocities are displayed. It is very interesting to note that dc,max/D increases almost linearly with ctgα at a given velocity. When the We number is kept constant, the slope of the line of dc,max/D versus ctgα is over two. In contrast, at the same value of ctgα, the rate of increase in dc,max/D with respect to V is less than 0.87. This means that variable ctgα plays a more important role in spread factors than the variable V when the drop impacts and deposits on a rotating disc. Fig. 12
The maximum tangential spread factor dc,max/D against ctgα for cases V = 1.98 and 3.13 m/s

sec.title: 4.4 Effects of falling and tangential velocities on the radial spread factor
sec.p: A drop falling on a stationary disc will spread uniformly in a circular manner. Similarly, the drop falling on a rotating disc will also experience a radial spread although the spread factor in the radial direction is usually less than that in the circumferential direction. Thus, it is interesting to know how the radial spread factor varies under different impact conditions.

Figure 13 depicts the effect of the tangential velocity on the evolution of both the radial and tangential spread factors. In Fig. 13(a), the impactradius Rs is 45 mm and the Ro number 5.53 while in Fig.12(b), they are 130.5 mm and 1.92, respectively. Itcan be observed that with the increase in the tangential velocity or decrease in Ro number, the difference between the maximum values of the tangential and radial spread factors rises apparently. Obviously, tangential velocity has little influence onthe maximum radial spread factor, dr,max/D, whereas dc,max/D rises linearly with 1/Ro number, as illustrated in Fig. 12. Fig. 13
Effect of tangential velocity on evolution of the radial and tangential spread factors, V = 1.98 m/s, n = 120 r/min: (a) Rs = 45 mm; (b) Rs = 130.5 mm

Figure 14 further verifies the variation tendency ofdr/D. Although Ro numbers in the spreading stage (Fig. 14(a) and (b)) are quite different, the impact processes show almost the same evolution curves of dr/D at a given V. In addition, the increase in V leads to a rise in dr,max/D. The rate of rise in dr,max/D with respect to V is about 0.87, which was also observed in Fig. 12 for dc,max/D versus V. Fig. 14
Effect of tangential velocity on evolution of radial spread factor under conditions n = 120 r/min, Rs = 45, 75, 100.5, and 130.5 mm: (a) V = 1.98 m/s (b) V = 3.13 m/s

Therefore, it can be concluded that the rotation of adisc mainly affects the tangential spread factor and has a little influence on the radial spread factor. However, the falling velocity exerts an evident influence on both dc/D and dr/D.

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
This article presents an experimental study on a water drop impacting on a rotating disc. The rotation of the disc has an appreciable effect on the water impact processes. Some conclusions can be drawn as follows:
Unlike the case for stationary surfaces, the deposition–splash boundary for a drop impacting on arotating disc was found to be a logarithmic function of the Re, We, and Ro numbers, on the basis of this experiment. The tangential velocity at theimpact point is a major factor for the occurrence of splash. In addition, increase in viscosity of the drop tends to promote splash while surface tension acts as an opposite function.
In the deposition process of a drop impacting on arotating disc, the Ro number plays an important role in dc/D but has little influence on dr/D. Inaddition, the dc,max/D increases almost linearly with the reciprocal of Ro number. The falling velocity of the drop has an obvious effect on both the tangential and the radial spread processes.
Several new deposition stages are observed in terms of Ro number: At a high value of Ro number, two new stages appear; at an intermediate value, three new stages are observed; while at a low value, there are only two new impact patterns in the deposition process.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the financial support provided by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under contract no. 50776066.
